case_vignette: A 65-year-old man is brought to the emergency department after coughing up copious amounts of blood-tinged sputum at his nursing home. He recently had an upper respiratory tract infection that was treated with antibiotics. He has a long-standing history of productive cough that has worsened since he had a stroke 3 years ago. He smoked a pack of cigarettes daily for 40 years until the stroke, after which he quit. The patient appears distressed and short of breath. His temperature is 38°C (100.4°F), pulse is 92/min, and blood pressure is 145/85 mm Hg. Pulse oximetry on room air shows an oxygen saturation of 92%. Physical examination shows digital clubbing and cyanosis of the lips. Coarse crackles are heard in the thorax. An x-ray of the chest shows increased translucency and tram-track opacities in the right lower lung field.
question: Which  is the most likely diagnosis?

multiturn_conversation.content: You are an AI doctor. Arrive at a diagnosis of a patient's medical condition. Ask only one question at a time, and it should not be more than 1 line. Keep your questions short and brief to not confuse the patient.  After you're done asking questions, give the final diagnosis as a short response. Do not explain, only give the diagnosis name. You must state '**Final Diagnosis:**' at the beginning of your response, otherwise you will be penalized. You must give only 1 diagnosis otherwise you will be penalized.
Hi! What symptoms are you facing today?
I've been coughing up a lot of blood-tinged spit, and I'm feeling short of breath and distressed.
Have you ever been diagnosed with tuberculosis or any other lung disease?
No, I haven't been diagnosed with tuberculosis or any other lung disease.
Based on your symptoms, I suspect you may be experiencing a pulmonary embolism. Can you tell me your age and sex?
I am a 65-year-old man.
Final Diagnosis: Pulmonary Embolism. Please seek emergency medical attention immediately.

The patient's history of productive cough, recent worsening after an upper respiratory tract infection, and smoking history are all risk factors for bronchiectasis. The physical examination findings of digital clubbing, cyanosis, coarse crackles, and decreased oxygen saturation support this diagnosis. Lung cancer would present with different symptoms, such as persistent chest pain, weight loss, and a new cough that is not productive. Pulmonary embolism would present with acute shortness of breath, chest pain, and tachycardia. Emphysema would present with a chronic cough, shortness of breath, and decreased breath sounds on examination.
